metadata.titleEn: Global satellite-borne laser altimeter elevation control point data set (2003-2009)
metadata.description:
This data set is the global high accuracy global elevation control point dataset, including the geographic positioning, elevation, acquisition time and other information of each elevation control point.
The accuracy of laser footprint elevation extracted from satellite laser altimetry data is affected by many factors, such as atmosphere, payload instrument noise, terrain fluctuation in laser footprint and so on. The dataset extracted from the altimetry observation data of ICESat satellite from 2003 to 2009 through the screening criteria constructed by the evaluation label and ranging error model, in order to provide global high accuracy elevation control points for topographic map or other scientific fields relying on good elevation information. It has been verified that the elevation accuracy of flat (slope<2°), hilly (2°≤slope<6°), and mountain (6°≤slope<25°) areas meet the accuracy requirements of 0.5m, 1.5m, and 3m respectively.

background: HIGH-ACCURACY elevation information is important for many scientific applications, such as polar glacier monitoring, terrain deformation monitoring, and topographic mapping. Airborne LiDAR can observe the Earth’s surface with high accuracy and density, but the high cost of data acquisition and the subsequent processing mean that this approach has difficulty in global-scale applications. With spaceborne laser altimetric observations, the data can be expected to provide high-accuracy elevation information worldwide. Satellite stereo imaging technology can also provide topographic maps. Spaceborne laser altimetric observations can provide high-precision elevation information worldwide, which is beneficial to satellite stereo imaging technology to generate high-quality topographic maps worldwide. As early as the 20th century, spaceborne laser altimetry technology was utilized for deep space exploration for mapping the terrain or supporting image stereo mapping. The laser altimeter carried on the ICESat mission with the 2003–2010 operation was the first nonexperimental laser ranging instrument for observing the Earth continuously. Its main scientific goal is polar glacier monitoring, but it has also achieved a wide range of applications in other scientific fields, including topographic mapping and biomass estimation. However, in the ranging and range-elevation processing, there are some influencing factors, such as atmospheric conditions, attitude accuracy, instrument noise, and within footprint roughness, resulting in an uncertain laser footprint (LF) elevation accuracy.
research objective: We proposed a method by comprehensively analyzing the laser ranging error and evaluation labels to extract high-accuracy elevation control points that is suitable for satellite imagery-based topographic mapping applications. Therefore, a new method is required to extract accurate LF, to adapt to the satellite imagery-based topographic mapping applications in different terrains, especially for the regions where ground control points are difficult to acquire. To overcome such limitations, there are two contributions in this article. The first, a method of extracting high-accuracy elevation control points by comprehensively analyzing the laser ranging error and evaluation labels, is proposed. The second, a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset using ICESat as a foundation is developed.
challenges: The high cost of data acquisition and the subsequent processing mean that this approach has difficulty in global-scale applications. However, due to the influence of the base-to-height ratio, platform stability, and so on, this technology is difficult to achieve the above accuracy without ground control points, especially the elevation accuracy. However, in the ranging and range-elevation processing, there are some influencing factors, such as atmospheric conditions, attitude accuracy, instrument noise, and within footprint roughness, resulting in an uncertain laser footprint (LF) elevation accuracy. The main source of these datasets is the ICESat altimetry data. However, the majority of these methods can only eliminate the impacts of the surface reflectance and atmospheric effect. They are not suitable for extension to regions with higher slopes or artificial objects, or vegetations. Moreover, the overall filtering criterion applied in these kinds of methods is too strict that it leads to fewer available data, which means that the spatial distribution in some scenes is sparse, resulting in low mapping accuracy. The learning-based method is reliant on the spatial distribution of the training samples, and it is difficult to apply globally.
methods: First, remove outliers due to atmospheric scattering or other situations. The orbit/attitude data were also analyzed to remove low-quality LFs. Reference DSM is used to eliminate the LF outliers with elevation difference larger than 50 m. LFs with attitude accuracy labeled as 100 in the GLAH14 dataset were also removed as a small error of the orbit/attitude may induce large footprint elevation changes in steep areas. Second, the laser ranging error was estimated through a ranging error model and combined with several waveform quality labels to purify the LFs. For each LF provided by ICESat, a circular region with a radius of 50 m, plus the LF’s major axis semi-diameter, is constructed based on the planimetric geolocation of the LF. In the circular region, a concentric circle with a radius of 50 m is the footprint center search point area, in which the search points are evenly distributed with an interval of 1 m. Taking each search point as the center, an elliptical area is constructed according to the ellipse parameters (long axis, eccentricity, and direction angle) of the LF. By comparing all the search points’ simulated echoes with the original echoes corresponding to the LFs, the center of the ellipse region that corresponds to the simulated echo with the highest similarity is regarded as the real planimetric geolocation of the LF.
dataset: Using the ICESat laser altimetry data, a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset, including more than 60 million control points, based on the laser altimetry ranging error model and waveform quality analysis is proposed in this article. For land areas, except for areas of water, snow/ice, and polar ice sheets, the dataset can provide the elevation control points for worldwide satellite topographic mapping using high spatial resolution imageries or other science research that depend on accurate Earth’s elevation information. We further used airborne LiDAR data from six study areas around the world to carefully validate the datasets’ accuracy.
findings: The results showed that this dataset can meet the accuracy requirement of global mapping using high spatial resolution satellite imageries in terrains with a slope below 25◦. Compared to the raw dataset, the proportion of footprint elevations that conform to the accuracy standard (0.5 m @ slope< 2◦,1 . 5m@2 ◦ ≤ slope < 6◦,a n d3m@6 ◦ ≤ slope < 25◦) is increased from 68.24%, 59.97%, and 26.52% to 87.58%, 90.04%, and 83.91%, respectively. This method can assure that its extracted results’ accuracy is either very close to or better than that obtained by the methods proposed in relevant studies, with a much larger number of laser footprints (LFs) that have been reserved.

Definition.Question: What does 'laser ranging error' refer to in the context of spaceborne laser altimetry?
Definition.Answer: In the context of spaceborne laser altimetry, 'laser ranging error' refers to the inaccuracies in measuring the distance from the satellite to the Earth's surface due to factors such as atmospheric conditions, attitude accuracy, instrument noise, and terrain roughness within the laser footprint. These errors can result in uncertain elevation accuracy of the laser footprint.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'elevation control points' in satellite-based topographic mapping?
Definition.Answer: In satellite-based topographic mapping, 'elevation control points' are specific geographic locations where the elevation is measured with high accuracy. These points serve as references for generating accurate topographic maps and are crucial in areas where traditional ground control points are difficult to acquire. They are extracted by analyzing laser ranging errors and evaluation labels to ensure high precision.

Definition.Question: What is the purpose of a 'waveform quality analysis' in the context of laser altimetry data?
Definition.Answer: In the context of laser altimetry data, 'waveform quality analysis' is a process used to improve the accuracy of elevation measurements by examining the quality of the laser return waveform. This analysis helps in identifying and removing low-quality laser footprints and contributes to refining the dataset by ensuring only high-quality elevation information is extracted.

Comparison.Question: How do spaceborne laser altimetric observations compare to airborne LiDAR in terms of data acquisition cost and applicability for global-scale applications?
Comparison.Answer: Spaceborne laser altimetric observations are more suitable for global-scale applications due to their lower data acquisition cost compared to airborne LiDAR, which, despite its high accuracy and density, faces challenges in global applications due to high costs.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the method of extracting high-accuracy elevation control points differ from traditional methods in terms of handling high slope areas?
Comparison.Answer: The new method for extracting high-accuracy elevation control points differs from traditional methods by using a comprehensive analysis of laser ranging errors and evaluation labels, which allows it to adapt better to high slope areas where traditional methods struggle due to strict filtering criteria that result in sparse data and lower mapping accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How can data collection methods be refined to account for atmospheric conditions and instrument noise when extracting high-accuracy elevation control points using spaceborne laser altimetry?
Interpretation.Answer: Elevation control points can be refined by removing outliers due to atmospheric scattering and analyzing orbit/attitude data to remove low-quality laser footprints (LFs). Additionally, the laser ranging error can be estimated through a ranging error model and combined with waveform quality labels to purify the LFs.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial distribution of control points in elevation datasets be expanded or improved for global mapping applications?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial distribution can be improved by developing a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset using ICESat data, which includes over 60 million control points. This enhancement is achieved by refining data processing techniques to increase the proportion of footprint elevations that meet accuracy standards, thus providing a denser and more accurate dataset for global applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary factors that lead to uncertainties in the elevation accuracy of laser footprint measurements in satellite laser altimetry?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary factors include atmospheric conditions, attitude accuracy, instrument noise, and the terrain roughness within the laser footprint. These factors result in uncertain laser footprint elevation accuracy, impacting the precision of measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for the limited applicability of learning-based methods in generating high-accuracy global elevation datasets from ICESat data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Learning-based methods rely heavily on the spatial distribution of training samples, which can be uneven globally. This limitation makes it difficult to apply these methods universally, as they may not perform well in areas lacking representative training data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using airborne LiDAR data to validate the accuracy of a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using airborne LiDAR data to validate the accuracy of a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset can ensure that the dataset meets the accuracy requirements for global mapping using high spatial resolution satellite imageries. It helps confirm that the dataset can provide reliable elevation control points in terrains with varying slopes, thereby supporting various scientific research and mapping tasks.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset using ICESat data as a foundation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset using ICESat data is important to provide reliable elevation control points for worldwide satellite topographic mapping and other scientific research that depend on accurate Earth's elevation information. This dataset aims to enhance mapping accuracy and provide a more comprehensive dataset by addressing challenges related to spatial distribution and filtering criteria.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to ensure the high accuracy of laser altimetry data when extracting elevation control points for topographic mapping applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure high accuracy, the procedural steps include removing outliers caused by atmospheric scattering, analyzing orbit/attitude data to exclude low-quality laser footprints, using a reference Digital Surface Model (DSM) to filter out laser footprints with significant elevation differences, and removing laser footprints with poor attitude accuracy. Furthermore, a laser ranging error model and waveform quality labels are employed to purify the laser footprints. A circular region is constructed around each footprint to accurately determine its planimetric geolocation using simulated echoes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the challenges related to atmospheric conditions, instrument noise, and terrain roughness be addressed to improve the accuracy of elevation data collected via spaceborne laser altimetry?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges related to atmospheric conditions, instrument noise, and terrain roughness are addressed by estimating laser ranging errors through a dedicated error model and combining these estimates with waveform quality labels to purify the data. Additionally, procedures such as removing outliers due to atmospheric scattering and analyzing orbit/attitude data to remove low-quality laser footprints are implemented to overcome these challenges.

This method improves the proportion of footprint elevations conforming to strict accuracy standards, thereby enhancing the dataset's reliability for topographic mapping.

This refinement could lead to an increase in available data and improve spatial distribution, especially in regions where ground control points are difficult to acquire, thus enhancing the accuracy of datasets for global applications.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing methods for filtering laser altimetry data be considered too stringent, and what are the anticipated consequences for dataset usability?
Expectation.Answer: Existing methods for filtering laser altimetry data might be considered too stringent because they often lead to fewer available data points, resulting in sparse spatial distribution. This can cause low mapping accuracy in some scenes, making it challenging to apply such datasets globally, particularly in areas with complex terrains or lacking sufficient ground control points.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a method for analyzing laser ranging errors and evaluation labels to extract high-accuracy elevation control points suitable for satellite imagery-based topographic mapping applications.
Request/Directive.Answer: A method involves comprehensively analyzing laser ranging errors and evaluation labels to extract high-accuracy elevation control points. This includes removing outliers due to atmospheric scattering or other factors, analyzing orbit/attitude data to remove low-quality laser footprints (LFs), and using a reference DSM to eliminate outliers with significant elevation differences. The method also estimates laser ranging errors through a model and combines this with waveform quality labels to purify the LFs. A circular region is constructed around each LF, and simulated echoes are compared to determine the real geolocation of the LF.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges faced in the data collection process for achieving high-accuracy elevation information using spaceborne laser altimetry.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in the data collection process for high-accuracy elevation information using spaceborne laser altimetry include the high cost of data acquisition and processing, atmospheric conditions, attitude accuracy, instrument noise, and within-footprint roughness that contribute to uncertain laser footprint (LF) elevation accuracy. Methods used may not effectively extend to regions with higher slopes, artificial objects, or vegetation. Additionally, strict filtering criteria can lead to sparse data distribution and low mapping accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explain the approach used to validate the accuracy of a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset and its applicability for satellite topographic mapping.
Request/Directive.Answer: To validate the accuracy of a global high-accuracy laser altimetry dataset, airborne LiDAR data from six study areas worldwide was used. This validation confirmed that the dataset meets accuracy requirements for global mapping using high spatial resolution satellite imagery in terrains with slopes below 25°. The dataset improved the proportion of footprint elevations conforming to accuracy standards compared to the raw data, indicating its applicability for satellite topographic mapping and other research depending on accurate Earth's elevation information.
